The rabbit bouncing in the ring had been waiting forever for this match. He had been working in house shows for a few years now, building up his fan base and paying his dues. One particularly raucous house show a few months ago impressed a talent scout enough to give him the shot at the big time he'd always wanted. It wasn't expected he would win, of course. He was too new, too raw for that. It would be embarrassing for one of the most established stars to lose to someone no one had ever seen before, after all. Still, it was a tremendous opportunity. The rabbit known as Kickstarter might be losing more matches than he wins for a year or so, but the point wasn't necessarily to win. It was to lose impressively enough that people still rooted for him. Besides, he had a trick or two up his sleeve that would make for a few surprises.

He bounced again, shaking his hands and rolling his shoulders. He was an impressive specimen of rabbit -- his brown fur was sleek and shined, both of his ears were long and perked. His spaded tail flickered through a hole in his wrestling trunks, and his paws were huge and strong. He wore a pair of black spandex pants that hugged his muscular legs, and the golden lightning bolt that lined the outsides of them only accentuated how long they really were. It was a simple look, but it had worked for him so far. He knew he was catching the eyes of the ladies in the audience, and likely a few of the men.

The referee, a gruff looking Yorkshire terrier who couldn't have been taller than five feet, stood in the middle of the ring. He held the microphone, looked out at the crowd, and opened his mouth for the announcements. His voice was gravelly, but it had a surprising boom to it.

"Ladies and gentlefurs, in this corner....standing at a height of six feet three inches tall, weighing in at 225 pounds...Kickstarter!"

There was a polite pop of applause for the stranger, but Kickstarter didn't mind. He sprung from his corner and promptly flipped, then cartwheeled, then leapt into a full tuck and spin in the air. His ears brushed the canvas with the last maneuver, and he stuck the landing right in front of the turnbuckle catty-corner from the one he started in. He raised his hands, then gave the crowd a wink and a flex. It might have been his imagination, but he could have sworn he heard the crowd cheer a little louder as his biceps peaked. They were warming to him already.

"And approaching the ring...standing at a towering nine feet and seven inches tall, and weighing in at 1,225 pounds...The Glacier!"

Kickstarter's eyes widened right before the lights went down. Did he just hear the announcer correctly? Laser lights and music came up, flashing around the arena before centering on the entrance. The music for this guy could barely be heard over the roar of the crowd. The rabbit could see flashes of the mob in the audience. They were on their feet, cheering and shouting. His ears folded for a moment. The Glacier was clearly *very* popular.

He followed the lights to the entrance, and filling it entirely was the biggest polar bear he had ever seen. He wore a unitard that stretched around a monstrously barreled torso. His chest, shoulders and back were so bullishly muscled it looked like the spandex was stretched to its breaking point. His stomach was fairly rounded, and a lot of the definition was muted by a layer of fat and fur that only served to make the ursine appear even more impenetrable. He looked around at the crowd, held up arms the size of tree trunks and roared. The sound drowned out everything else -- the music, the crowd, and the beating in Kickstarter's own heart.

The bear then lumbered down the ramp onto the arena floor. His legs were bear and so were his paws. They slammed against the metal grating, and Kickstarter watched them shiver from the impact of all that weight. Even the concrete seemed to tremble when he got to the floor outside the ring. Standing on the apron, the bear's eyes looked over the top rope easily.

The Glacier grinned as he jumped from the apron, over the ropes and into the ring. He landed with a tremendous slam that forced Kickstarter to stumble back into his turnbuckle. The referee was thrown onto his rump, and used the opportunity to roll out of the ring. Kickstarter was beginning to think that the terrier had the right idea. The enormous bear thumped to the center of the ring, looming over the rabbit even there, and put his paws on his hips. His shoulders were so broad his head seemed to disappear right into them. Maybe he stopped where he did because he would lose his opponent under his pecs if he got any closer.

"Oh, look. It's little bunny." The Glacier rumbled in a thick Russian accent as the lights came up. "It will be fun to break you like twig."

Kickstarter forced his ears to come up as he stared defiantly up at the bear. The Glacier had crisp, sharp blue eyes that would have been attractive on anyone else. On him, it was just terrifying.

"You're going to have to catch me first, you big lummox." The rabbit began to bounce on his long paws, preparing himself for the work ahead.

152212.title: Fear of the Tessler

1522122.content:
The cafeteria tables are set up around the floor, awaiting hungry lunch goers. In the back of the room, you see the kitchen. And attempting to hide between two tables you see him.

You snarl with fury as you look this pathetic creature over. It's a weasel. A rather burly weasel, but a weasel nonetheless. If you weren't boiling with rage, you'd be able to appreciate the humor of the situation. As it is, though, you can hardly see through your anger. Your very essence seems to resonate with fury. You can feel the anger like electricity in your hands. The cowardly weasel uncurls just enough to peek a single eye at you before he curls up into an ever tighter ball.

That's the last straw.

You stomp over to the quivering mass, each step causing every table, chair, and vending machine in the cafeteria to shake violently. As your hand swoops down upon it, it attempts to curl up even tighter than it already has. That will do it no good. You grab him by the back of his neck and lift him up to eye level. He remains stubbornly curled up.

"Open up," you say quietly. It's the kind of quiet of a boulder at the precipice of a cliff. Perfectly collected. Perfectly balanced. And if one wrong move is made, perfectly deadly. It's a quietness that promises endless punishment if not obeyed. The weasel catches on. He uncurls.

You look him up and down appraisingly. Huge, perfectly symmetrical muscles. Expensive trunks. Even an expensive haircut. You know his type. He was the biggest, baddest guy at the gym and thought he might try the big time. Thought he could handle it. Wanted some attention. But when he heard about what you've done to your past foes, he ran scared. Disgusting.

"Give me one reason why I shouldn't kill you know," you say, the edge in your voice sharp enough to slice through steel.

He avoids your eyes, trembling like a leaf, glancing around wildly, looking for any sort of salvation.

"Well," you say, a slight hint of impatience whetting your statement, "I'm waiting."

"I-" he says, looking down at the linoleum, "I-"

"Yes?" you say, the smell of his terror filling your nostrils. Intoxicating. You're going to enjoy this.

"I was- I was just gonna-" he says desperately, his eyes locked on the floor.

"Gonna what?" you say, holding him closer to your face. He's barely a foot away. You can smell his panicky breath.

"Gonna- gonna-" he stutters, at a loss.

"Look at me," you say plainly. He doesn't. Grabbing his chin, you wrench his face to face yours. For one brief second, his gaze is focused entirely on yours. His eyes widen, a ring of white encircling the blue of his eyes, before his eyes go out of focus. "Now," you say with terrible patience. "I'm going to tell you again. Give me one good reason why I shouldn't kill you." You ease your grip on his jaw enough to allow him to talk.

He mouths wordlessly for a few moments before dissolving into tears. Sobs burst through his throat, tears stream down his cheek pathetically. It's disgusting.

"Please don't kill me!" he gasps through his sobs. "I've got so much to give."

"Shut up," you say, your voice softer and more deadly now than it ever has been. He continues to bawl. "SHUT UP!" you roar. The very room trembles with your roar. The pathetic creature is immediately silent, though tears still stream down his face. You hold him mere inches from your face. "There is nothing worse in the world than a coward. Before you die tonight, and I give you my word, you will die tonight, I am going to make you wish you had never been born."

You toss him down to the ground and turn around, walking back to the cafeteria doors. With only a little effort on your part, you rip a vending machine from the wall and slam it down in front of the door, blocking the coward's exit. You look back to where the coward lay trembling.
1522122.title: The cowardly weasel

15221221.content:
You snarl in fury. The spot where the weasel was is now empty. Then you hear it. A sobbing, scrambling sound, coming from the tables. He's trying to escape.

With a roar, you plow through the tables, flipping them out of your way one right after the other. You don't even notice as they crash down, smashing tiles into pieces as they go. Finally you reach the weasel. He's flipped onto his back and looks up at you with utter terror. You bend down to pick him up, fury coursing through your veins. Then he makes the biggest, and last, mistake in his life.

He kicks you in the face.

You rear back. You're bewildered, as if your mind is already so furious that it can't possibly process any more anger. Then you taste blood on your lips. Your own blood.

Your vision goes red. You've never been this angry before. It's as if you're watching the scene before you from just behind your vision. It's almost unreal, your fury, as if it has a personality all its own. Then, like a snapping wire, your mind and your fury slam together.

Power explodes through your veins. Anger seethes in your very muscles. You double over in exquisite pain, snarling. You feel your vest grow tight around your chest before snapping. The belts that hold the steel breastplates over your two sets of genitalia are the next to go. Your wrists are in fiery pain as the quickly grow too big for the steel bracers around them until, with a sharp snapping sound, they explode off of you and clatter to the ground.

At last, the exquisite pain ends and you're able to stand straight again. You know you're bigger. You can feel it. It feels right. The world is suddenly perfectly clear to you. Right now, there are only two things: Your prey, and making him suffer. You look towards the kitchen and see the weasel quickly duck out of sight behind the lunch line. There's no need for you to rush. You begin to walk towards the kitchen. You don't even bother flipping tables out of your way. With ease, your mighty footfalls simply smash them to pieces. Your leisurely pace is not even inhibited. You stop when you reach the kitchen door. The door doesn't even come up to your navel. Without another thought, you punch one arm, then another, through the wall. It hardly resists. You smash your head through next. Through the dust, you make out the shape of your opponent. He's desperately struggling with the locked door leading out of the kitchen. He looks at you and the hole you effortlessly made in the concrete wall with unbridled terror.

You smile and push your way through the wall. As you walk towards the weasel, his struggles become more and more pathetic.

"Please!" he shouts, banging on the unrelenting door. "Someone help! He's going to kill me!"

You soon reach him and, wrapping a huge hand around him, you throw him at the opposite wall. His back smashed into it, cracking the stone wall. You quickly cover the ground between you and him and wrap your hand around his chest. He's obviously dazed. You wait a moment for his head to clear. He soon looks at you straight again.

"Please no," he begs weakly.

You lift him up and slam him into a stainless steel table, bending the table top until it reaches half way to the ground. You pick him up again and slam him into the cast iron of a gas stove, loving the sound of his howls as the uneven surface wreaks havoc on his back. You lift him up one last time and hurl him at another wall. He smashed into it and collapses to the ground.

As you stride to him, he desperately tries to drag himself away. You grab him by the legs, pull him under you, then lift him up by his left arm. You gently take hold of his right arm and, slowly, very slowly, you increase the pressure. His anguish is like honey to you. His howls for mercy echo of the slick countertops of the kitchen.

Finally, you feel his arm snap between your fingers.

He screams in pain before passing out.

How to wake him up, you wonder...

15411111.content:
"CHUG! CHUG! CHUG!" the crowd chant. You smile around the dazed Bruce, and oblige. The first swallow pulls the Roo's head and chest completely. Something snaps inside the Roo's head and he begins to struggle violently, kicking his legs and whirling his tail. You smile wider around him and swallow again, taking half his chest inwards. You can hear his frantic swearing as he struggles to escape, not knowing he's only forcing himself deeper and deeper. As the third swallow pulls his hips into your mouth and immobilises all but his feet and tail, you feel his head entering your forestomach and purr, making sure the nearest microphone can pick it up. You also hear, very faintly, the Roo's swearing through the speakers... "fuck... It got me... Gotta get... bloody loose..." You smile, and swallow for the penultimate time. The roo's shoulders and chest enter your belly, his feet slipping into your maw. You smile wider, opening your mouth wide. A cameraman aims his camera directly into your mouth and, keeping your jaws apart, you swallow for the final time. On the big screens, the roo's feet and tail dissapear from view and, a few seconds later, the stomach on your humanoid section swells with the weight of the roo. He keeps struggling and you smile, rubbing your forestomach with one hand, holding the other high.

"AND HERE IS YOUR WINNER!" The ref shouts "THE ALIEN INVADER... MARDACAI!!!!"

Your next fight is...

1541112221121122221122.content:
You bring the Learjet-sized dropship into the main hangar of the ICS Mardacai's Fire and turn to look at your passengers. All are silent, awed by the sheer size of the ICS Mardacai's Fire, a six mile long, two mile wide heavy cruiser that you call home.

Hogan speaks, voicing what you're sure the others are thinking. "Shit" he says simply "I knew the ship was big but... huge doesn't encompass it..." "Aye" you reply as you unbuckle them from their couches. "She's a Ralakir class heavy cruiser, and her class are the biggest vessels ever to leave the Thebe's Moon shipyards. There are only nine in existance, and they're given to high-ranking Imperial Chakat Navy officials when they leave. I was an Admiral of the Fleet, before I became an explorer. To your left, you can see my little runabout, an ICF Storm-class heavy fighter, my own design." You guesture towards a smaller ship that looks like a cross between a Star Wars Y-wing and an A-10 Thunderbolt II Warthog tankbuster as the outer doors of the hangar shut and the bay is repressurised.

The ramp lowers and you lead your new friends into the hangar bay itself. A huge mural covers one wall of the bay, at least a hundred feet tall and four hundred feet wide; the view from your old apartment on Chakona prime. It features a tropical-type beach at night. The starscape is unrecognisable, and strange palm-like trees and green sand are reflected by a silvery sea. 7/8 of a huge, blue-green ringed moon is visible over the horizon, also reflected by the sea. Tsun catches sight of it first. "Is that your home, Mardacai-sama?" she asks, pointing at the mural. "Is very beautiful." You nod. "Thebe's Moon rising over Tarkla Beach, Chakona Prime." you answer. "Enlarged from a painting I did just before I left the Navy. Its a little piece of home..." They all nod, seeming in awe "Pretty..." Ellysa remarks, faintly. The three non-wrestlers are silent, examining the image.

After letting them gaze for a while, you lead them through the ship, showing them first the huge engine room that contains two massive fusion reactors that generate power for the whole ship and the twelve advanced monopolium-catalyst fusion engines that can propel the vessel at up to ten times Light speed. "These engines," you explain "are deuterium fusion engines, catalysed by Magnetic Monopolium, an exotic element that, just as its name says, is magnetic. Unlike iron, however, Monopolim doesn't have north and south poles; it has one OR the other, making it usefull for reactors like this. The engines alternate; six are North-catalysed, six are South. They kick out a hell of a lot of power and push the ship at the equivalent of ten times light speed. They also encompass the ship in an energy field which counters the relativistic effects of travelling so fast, meaning that if the outside world sees our voyage as two years, so do we. They drink a lot of fuel though- there are six million metric tonnes of water in the fuel tanks, for generating the hydrogen needed to make deuterium." You can tell by their glazed expressions that your little speach has sailed right over the heads of everyone except Tsun, who seems to have filed all the data away for later perusal, a thougfull expression in her deep brown eyes. You make a note to keep an eye on her; she could be extremely useful; she's got intelligence, and interest; a future chief engineer, perhaps...?

You show them the rest of the ship; the bed rooms, galleys, Refreshers (toilet/wash rooms), Recreational complexes, sauna/jaccuzi rooms, various themed "fun rooms" including a zero-g room with a 360-degree view of the outside stars and a "bouncy" room, again in zero-G but with inflatable cushioning on the walls, floor and cieling and various inflatables, and rooms that cater for almost all tastes and kinks in the known universe. You then show them their rooms, your quarters and finally, the centre-piece of the whole vessel, the magificent bridge that is 300 ft wide, 300 ft deep and 400 tall...

On the main screen, two hundred and fifty feet across and three hundred foot tall, is a huge panorama of the Earth and the moon with various status displays in your own language. The Day/Night border is visible, meaning half the world is blue-green and the other half is black and lit up with countless lines and blobs of light. You point to one of the blobs. "That" you say, enlarging it. "Is New York city, where we just were. Pretty, isn't it?" Your six guests nod. "I've just got to wait for Joe to bring the second Drop-ship up and then we can head out." you continue "Seeing as nobody but the crew can be present on board an Imperial Chakat Starvessel, I'd like to welcome you all to my crew. We can celebrate once we're on the move- Joe'll show you where to get your uniforms and log your DNA signatures into the Auto-Reformation system. That way, we can do all the Vore we want, safely." They all grin, still looking a little disbelieving. "You don't believe me?" you say, faking offence. "Ask Joe when he gets here. He's been on my crew for sixteen years, since I rescued him from Slavers near what you call Betelgeuse. Chakats ain't stupid- A species which likes being both predator and prey ain't gonna last long without a system like that..." You chuckle, watching the drop-ship approach on the scanner as Joe brings it into the dock, nowhere near as smooth as you were.

A light begins to flash on the communications console informs you that your "Alien" (meaning not born on Earth) human trainer, "Big" Joe Capezza, has just brought the second drop-ship in and sealed the hangar. "Alright, we're ready to go. Give me a course!"

The skunkmorph grins "How about" he says in a nervous tone. "Take the third star on the right and straight on 'till morning!"

You chuckle, thinking 'Trekkie'- you remember that as the last line from one of the Star Trek films. 'Might be usefull as helm' you note.

After the tour, you hear Bruce speaking from your womb. "What about me?" he asks petulantly. "Don't I get to see it all?" You'll decide that later, so you ignore him.

So.... Where are you going to go?
